Dear Ms. Melendrez:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
A six-month provisional license is recommended based on special investigation
2023C0000500. If you do not contest the issuance of a provisional license, you must
indicate so in writing, on the attached document. If you contest the issuance of a
provisional certificate of approval, you must notify this office in writing and an
administrative hearing will be scheduled. Even if you contest the issuance of a provisional
license, you must still submit an acceptable corrective action plan.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Cathrine Raftery, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 06/11/23, while two staff were supervising, Youth A alleged
that Youth B purposely touched her butt and chest while they were
playing. Youth B denied this, saying they were just running
around. There is no known history of allegations against Youth B.
There are cameras in the area where this occurred, and they are
being reviewed.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on June
14, 2023. Youth A reported she has been at the facility for a
couple of months and things are going well. She reported she
really likes Staff 2 and trusts her. Youth A reported she told Staff 2
that on June 11, 2023, Youth B touch her butt and chest while
they were in the kitchen helping Staff 1 cook. She reported that
made her feel uncomfortable because he did it when staff were
2

not looking. Youth A reported she told Staff 1 and Staff 2 about
these concerns and now Youth B has to stay 10 feet away from
her. Consultant asked Youth A where the staff were when this
occurred and she reported Staff 1 was in the kitchen cooking with
them, Staff 2 was with two other youths down the hallway, and
Staff 3 was in the living room watching tv with the two other youth.
Youth A reported the staff do a good job of supervising the youth
and Youth B did it when the staff was not looking. She reported
she believes Youth C saw this occur when they were walking past
the kitchen.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on June
14, 2023. Youth B reported he has been placed at the facility for a
little over a month and feels safe at the facility. He reported the
staff treat him well and keep him safe. Youth B reported he has a
good relationship with Staff 1 and can go to him when he needs
help. He reported Staff 1 spoke to him the other day to remind him
about personal boundaries and reported Youth A stated he
touched her on her butt and chest area. Youth B reported that
never happened. He stated he believes Youth A is telling staff that
because she wanted to date him, and he does not want to date
her. Youth B reported because Youth A told staff those concerns;
they now need to stay 10 feet away from one another. He reported
the staff at the facility do a good job at supervising the youth.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on June
14, 2023. Youth C reported on June 11, 2023, she was walking by
the kitchen area and heard Youth A tell Youth B to stop. She
reported she heard later from Youth A that Youth B touched her
butt and chest. Youth C reported she did not see anything actually
occur. She reported because of this reported concern, Youth A
and Youth B are to be ten feet away from one another. Youth C
reported staff does a good job at supervising the youth. She
stated Staff 1 was in the kitchen with Youth A and Youth B when
this occurred. Youth C reported Staff 1 was cooking so there was
no way he could have had direct eyes on the youth. She reported
she was being supervised by Staff 2 when this occurred.
Staff 1/Complaint Source was interviewed face to face at the
facility on June 14, 2023. Staff 1 reported Youth A disclosed to
him on June 11, 2023, that Youth B had touched her butt and
breast area over her clothes while they were in the living room
area. He reported he spoke to Youth B about this reported
concern and Youth B denied that this happened. Staff 1 reported
during the time Youth A reported this he was cooking dinner in the
kitchen, Youth A and Youth B also came in there at one point to
3

help. He reported Staff 3 was in the main living room watching tv
with a couple of youth and Staff 2 was in the hallway with another
youth. Staff 1 reported the staffing ratio is one staff to every two
youth unless heightened supervision is needed which reported
Youth A and Youth B was not on. He stated staff are to
communicate with one another about the whereabout of the youth
and general supervision means eyes on the youth. Staff 1
reported he told Staff 2 and Staff 3 he was going to be cooking so
that they were aware he was not watching the living room areas.
He stated staff should have eyes on the youth when they are all in
the living room areas and should be interacting with the youth.
Staff 1 reported he never saw Youth B touch Youth A. He stated
after the disclosure a safety plan was put into place where Youth
A and Youth B should be always ten feet apart.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 14,
2023. Staff 2 reported on June 11, 2023, she was down one of
the hallways with Youth C and another female youth. She reported
Youth A came up to her and asked to speak in private. Youth A
disclosed Youth B had touched her breast and butt over her
clothes when they were in the living room. Staff 2 reported after
that disclosure, Youth A also told Staff 1, and Staff 2 talked with
Youth B. She reported Youth B denied that it happened. To make
sure they were safe, a safety plan was put into place to keep the
youth ten feet apart and increased supervision level. Staff 2
reported she did not see the touching occur. She reported Staff 1
was in the kitchen during the time the incident was reported to
have happened and he was making dinner for the unit. Staff 2
reported Staff 3 was supervising the main living room area during
that time as Staff 2 was keeping an eye on the hallway with Youth
C and another female youth. She reported Staff 3 had a negative
attitude on the shift due to another investigation happening with
her and she was on her cell phone a lot during the shift. Staff 2
reported she had no concerns with Staff 1’s ability to do his job
and is very engaging with the youth. She stated Staff 1
communicated to everyone he was cooking dinner for the unit.
Staff 2 reported the supervision policy is that eyes should be on
the youth when they are out in the living area and that they should
be interacting with the youth. She reported the ratio is 2 youth to
every 1 staff member during waking areas. Staff 1 reported
everyone on the team was notified of the safety plan between
Youth A and Youth B and the appropriate distance that needed to
be had.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face to face at the
facility on June 14, 2023, and via phone on June 23, 2023.
4

Chief Administrator reported she was not working that shift when
the incident was reported to have occurred. She reported she
heard from Staff 1 and Staff 2 that Youth A disclosed this
allegation to them. Chief Administrator reported both Youth A and
Youth B were previously not on any safety plan with heightened
supervision and there has been no concern with either youth
sexually acting out. She reported staff are supposed to have eyes
on supervision when youth are in the milieu area and the ratio is
two youth to one staff member during waking hours. Currently,
they have six youth placed at the facility and that means during
waking hours they need to have three staff members working.
This consultant asked for the Chief Administrator to speak about
the general supervision policy. When asked about the statement,
“staff will provide visual supervision to ensure safety”, Chief
Administrator explained the definition of "visual" is that staff can
see the youth at all times, and they are in the line of sight.
Staff 3 was attempted to be interviewed via phone on June
16, 2023, and June 22, 2023. Voicemails were left for Staff 3 for
each call requesting a callback and there was no return phone
call. On June 14, 2023, Chief Administrator reported Staff 3 is no
longer employed with the facility.
Video Footage:
Video footage regarding the reported allegation from June 11,
2023, involving Youth B touching Youth A was reviewed on June
20, 2023. The video footage is dated 6-11-23, time-stamped, and
begins at 05:58 pm. At the start of the video from the
kitchen/dining room, Youth A and Youth B are walking in and out
of the kitchen bringing items to the dining room area. There is no
direct camera in the kitchen, so there is no viewing of staff. At
5:59:30pm, Youth B signaled to Youth A to come over and the
camera view is moved to the East Living Room. Youth A and
Youth B enter the East Living Room and Youth B puts his finger
up to his mouth to signal to be quiet to Youth A. Youth B then took
one finger and pressed it on Youth A’s chest. Youth A then
flinched and ran out of the East Living Room at 05:59:59pm back
into the kitchen/ dining room area and Youth B followed. Within
the kitchen video, Youth A and Youth B go back to moving items
around in the dining room. At 06:01:50, Staff Member 2 popped
their head out of the cut-out window from the kitchen area to
check in on Youth A and Youth B in the dining room area.
Facility Tour:
On 06/14/2023, this consultant toured the facility to understand
the lay of the facility. When you walk into the main living area, you
5

walk into a large multi-use area with a table and chair. To the right
of the main room, is one living room area with a couch, chair, and
tv set. This area was noted where Staff 3 was during the incident.
Past this living room area, there is a hallway leading to the
bedrooms down that hall. This area is where it was noted Staff 2
was supervising. To the left of the main room is the second living
area which is noted in the video of the East Living room, where
the incident occurred. The kitchen is next to this area and has a
partial opening to the main room as well.
Documentation:
-Supervision Guidelines Adrian Treatment Facility updated
06/09/2023- This form is hung up in the staff office for the staff to
note a snapshot of each youth’s level of supervision and
diagnoses. Youth A is noted to have general supervision at home,
school, and in the community. It notes visual supervision while in
the restroom to ensure proper hygiene. Youth A has been
diagnosed with mild intellectual disability, PTSD, anxiety, DM,
language, and social disorder. Youth B is noted to have general
supervision at home, school, and in the community. Youth B has a
history of aggression, oppositional, and manipulative behaviors.
Youth B should have visual supervision while in the restroom to
ensure proper hygiene. Youth B’s diagnose are PTSD, ADHD,
ODD, RAD, and Precocious Puberty. On the bottom of the paper,
it notes, “General supervision: While in general areas of the home
and bedroom, staff will provide visual supervision to ensure safety.
Auditory supervision will be provided while in the bathroom or
when youth is asleep. During non-awake hours, 15-minute visual
bed checks will be performed. Visual supervision will be
maintained while in the community unless otherwise specified.”
- Facility Staffing Requirements and Supervision Policy dated
11/10/2021- Policy notes the staffing ratio is one staff to two
clients during waking hours. Staff will provide supervision as
specified in the client’s service plan.
- Safety Plan for Youth A and Youth B- Facility put the current
safety plan in place for the youth involved right after the disclosure
from Youth A. The following email was sent out to all staff, “due to
allegations of inappropriate touching made by Youth A against
Youth B, they are to remain at least 10ft apart at all times and their
interactions must be closely monitored.”
- Youth A’s Initial Service Plan completed by the facility dated
05/24/2023– The report notes no concerns of sexualized behavior.
The report noted supervision guidelines for Youth A as followed:
6

“While in general areas of the home and bedroom, staff will
provide visual supervision to ensure safety.”
- Youth B’s Initial Service Plan completed by the facility dated
05/22/2023- The report notes no concerns of sexualized behavior.
The report noted supervision guidelines for Youth B as followed:
“While in general areas of the home and bedroom, staff will
provide visual supervision to ensure safety.”
- Email from Compliance Manager dated
06/20/2023- Compliance Manager is the manager who gathered
the video footage and reviews the video footage for the facility. He
reported there are no cameras directly inside the kitchen.
Compliance Manager reported he viewed the video footage before
the saved video of this Consultant review. He reported several
youth, including Youth A and Youth B were helping with dinner
prep that evening with Staff 1 in the kitchen. Staff 2 was in and out
of the kitchen during the previous videos a couple of times before
she went back inside the kitchen. Staff 2 is seen on the video
poking her head out of the “serving window/counter area”.
Compliance Manager reported he did not save the video clips that
he reviewed from anything prior regarding supervision and youths'
movements in and out of the kitchen. He noted that he did not see
anything that would be in non-compliance when he was reviewing
the initial complaint and saved the video of the actual incident that
occurred, which is what this consultant reviewed.
- Email from Law Enforcement dated 06/21/2023- Law
Enforcement reported Youth B did admit to him that he touched
Youth A after Law Enforcement stated he saw it on video.
-Email from Youth A’s Foster Care worker dated
06/14/2023- Youth A’s foster care reported she did not have any
information pertaining to the allegations and noted that Youth A
has been involved in another investigation.
- Email from Youth B’s Foster Care Worker dated
06/13/2023- Youth B’s Foster Care reported this was the first time
she has received an incident report regarding inappropriate
touching.
- Human Resource (HR) files and Training Logs for Staff 1,
Staff 2, and Staff 3- Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 all had corrective
action plans noted within their HR Files for not following the
agency crisis interview procedures in an appropriate way. There
were no noted concerns in the HR files for all three staff about the
7

lack of supervision of the youth. Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 are all
up to date on their required trainings. Each staff member was
trained in the supervision policy during their orientation training
shifts noted on their training hours. Staff 1 completed this training
on 04/17/2023, Staff 2 completed this training on 05/18/2023, and
Staff 3 completed this training on 07/29/2022.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance of adhering to their general
supervision policy. The general supervision policy notes visual
supervision, while in general areas of the home and bedroom,
staff will provide visual supervision to ensure safety. It was found
there was a time-period were Youth A and Youth B were not
under general supervision which allowed Youth B to touch Youth
A.
Technical Assistance:
Assistance was provided to update the facility’s supervision policy
as it notes that supervision guidelines will be noted in the youth’s
case service plans which these plans are updated every 90 days
and could be missing if a youth is put on a heightened safety plan
during that time period. Suggestions were also provided to update
the language around ratio guidelines as it was found to be
confusing. It was also suggested to make sure that variable
interval room checks are occurring less than fifteen minutes apart
when a youth is within their bedroom.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, in conjunction with the recommendation of
SIR 2023C0000500, a First Provisional license is recommended upon receipt on an
acceptable corrective action plan.
